The "Rail Shipper Fairness Act of 2017" aims to improve rail service. The "Rail Shipper Fairness Act of 2017" includes amendments to common carrier obligations, emergency service orders, and liability for damages sustained by a person due to a carrier's violation of regulations. The "Rail Shipper Fairness Act of 2017" includes amendments to common carrier obligations, emergency service orders, and liability for damages. The amendments allow the Board to order a rail carrier to pay damages or provide equitable relief for inadequate service. Civil penalties under Section 11901 are increased to $25,000 in subsections (a) and (c), and to $1,000 in subsection (e). IMPROVING RAIL COMPETITION. The "Rail Shipper Fairness Act of 2017" amends rail transportation policy to protect the shipping public, allows shippers to obtain rates from multiple rail carriers, and defines effective competition in terms of existing infrastructure. The "Rail Shipper Fairness Act of 2017" amends rail transportation policy to protect the shipping public by allowing shippers to obtain rates from multiple rail carriers and defining market dominance in terms of existing infrastructure. The Act also requires Class I rail carriers to enter into competitive switching agreements upon petition from shippers or receivers demonstrating the need. The Rail Shipper Fairness Act of 2017 allows shippers served by a single Class I rail carrier to request competitive switching with another carrier within a reasonable distance. Competitive switching may not be imposed if it is deemed infeasible or unsafe, or if it unduly restricts a rail carrier's ability to serve its own shippers. The Board will develop a new methodology for determining the reasonableness of challenged rail rates based on competitive rate benchmarking, presuming rates above the benchmark level are unreasonable unless proven otherwise by the rail carrier. The Rail Shipper Fairness Act of 2017 introduces a new benchmarking method for determining the reasonableness of challenged rail rates. Relief under this method has no monetary limit, and any rate prescription set by the Board must remain in effect for at least 5 years. The Board's rulemaking will establish a standard procedural schedule for such cases, with a maximum duration of 365 days. Additionally, the Act prohibits rail carriers from changing challenged rates for transportation subject to the Board's jurisdiction. Additionally, the Board may not use cross-subsidy tests in deciding stand-alone cost cases and shall use a market-based revenue divisions methodology. If the Board determines that the rail carrier is revenue adequate in a stand-alone cost case, the rail carrier must prove that it is charging a reasonable rate. The Rail Shipper Fairness Act of 2017 introduces a new benchmarking method for determining the reasonableness of challenged rail rates. The Act prohibits rail carriers from changing challenged rates for transportation subject to the Board's jurisdiction. The Board may not use qualitative analysis to identify feasible transportation alternatives for shippers. The Rail Shipper Fairness Act of 2017 prohibits rail carriers from using an index to establish fuel surcharges. Fuel surcharges must be directly tied to actual fuel prices and cannot exceed incremental cost increases. Shippers can challenge unreasonable fuel surcharges under specified conditions. The Board is authorized to require carriers to report actual fuel prices. SEC. 6. REVENUE ADEQUACY.

The Rail Shipper Fairness Act of 2017 prohibits rail carriers from using an index to establish fuel surcharges. Fuel surcharges must be directly tied to actual fuel prices and cannot exceed incremental cost increases. Shippers can challenge unreasonable fuel surcharges under specified conditions. The Board is authorized to require carriers to report actual fuel prices. Amendment to Section 10704(a) of title 49, United States Code eliminates the Revenue Adequacy Test and introduces a new method for calculating a rail carrier's cost of capital.
